Technical Assistance Report 
Project Number: 52330-001 
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
June 2019 
 
 
 
 
Mongolia: Improving Extractive Sector Governance 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB’s Access to Information 
Policy.
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
(as of 18 June 2019)

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The Government of Mongolia requested knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) 
from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to support the Ministry of Mining and Heavy Industry 
(MMHI) in increasing transparency and public engagement in the extractive industry. This will 
improve governance of the industry, strengthening its contribution to Mongolia’s development and 
improve its attractiveness to prospective investors. This request is in line with objective 2 of the 
government’s  Mongolia  Sustainable  Development  Vision  2030  strategy  to  encourage  a 
transparent and accountable extractive industry and improve the competitiveness of mining.1 
Through  the  TA,  ADB  will  enhance  engagement  by  Mongolia  in  the  Extractive  Industries 
Transparency Initiative (EITI), increase public awareness of and engagement in mining activities, 
and provide guidance on legislative changes.2 The TA is included in the country operations 
business plan for Mongolia, 2019–2021.3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Mongolia’s extractive industry has grown rapidly since 2000, and now accounts for about 
90% of Mongolia’s exports and at least 24% of fiscal revenues. Mongolia also has vast untapped 
potential in coal and mineral resources. The country has about 10% of known global coal reserves 
and the world’s fourth-largest copper reserves, among many other minerals. After initial success 
in the 2000s in developing the extractive industry through foreign investment, the industry’s 
complexity has grown considerably. This is understandable as it brings together several layers of 
government,  international  and  domestic  private  sector,  as  well  as  civil  society  and  local 
communities. Such a sector requires a clear vision with broad buy-in that reflects the current 
situation in the sector and a transparent and rules-based legislative framework that underpins the 
rights of local communities, business and other stakeholders. 
 
3.  The industry lacks a consolidated and coordinated policy. The government’s most recent 
attempt to craft such a policy—the state minerals policy, 2014–2025—has been stalled by 
numerous  changes  within  the  MMHI  and  is  effectively  dormant.4  The  industry’s  legislative 
framework hinges on different laws that are perceived as being inconsistent and outdated. 
Development  partners  have  provided  significant  support  and  advice  to  the  government  to 
strengthen legislation, including preparing drafts of a new mining law and draft amendments to 
the minerals law. Approval of these updates is awaiting consensus among stakeholders about a 
common vision for the industry. The system for allocating mineral revenues between the central 
and local governments is opaque and poorly understood. The system is supposed to allocate 
funds to local governments based on development needs, and to favor aimags (provinces) with 
mining projects. However, funding from the General Local Development Fund, where these 
revenues are pooled, decreased dramatically after 2015, and it is generally believed that the 
system fails to incentivize aimags to encourage mining investment. 
 
4.  Mongolia has made good progress in transparency. Mongolia first started implementing 
the EITI standard in 2006 and is one of six countries (out of 51) that meet all EITI requirements. 
                                                
1  Government of Mongolia. 2016. Mongolia Sustainable Development Vision 2030. Ulaanbaatar. 
2  The EITI sets a global standard for good governance in oil, gas, and mineral resources and has 51 member countries.  
3  ADB. 2018. Country Operations Business Plan: Mongolia, 2019–2021. Manila. The business plan lists the TA project 
name as Develop an Information System to Strengthen Governance of Extractive Sector. The name has been 
changed in agreement with the government to better reflect the scope, which will include more than just information 
systems. The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 26 April 2019. 
4  Government of Mongolia. 2014. The State Policy of Mongolia in Respect of the Minerals Sector for 2014–2025. 
Ulaanbaatar.

2 
However, this momentum appears to have stalled. Oversight of the National EITI Secretariat was 
transferred from the Prime Minister’s Office to the MMHI in 2018 but without adequate budgetary 
allocations.  World  Bank  funding  for  the  secretariat  ended  in  2018,  leaving  the  secretariat 
unfunded. For Mongolia to continue to meet EITI requirements, the country needs to make 
progress on transparency of beneficial ownership and contracts by 2020, before validation by the 
international EITI secretariat in 2021.5 Political support to require companies to publish more 
information on beneficial ownership—a requirement that was introduced as part of the new EITI 
standard in 2016—is uncertain. 
 
5.  A  multistakeholder  group  composed  of  government,  civil  society,  and  business 
representatives oversees the national EITI process. The group has highlighted the importance of 
strengthening engagement with the EITI as growing complexity in the extractive industry, coupled 
with hotly contested elections scheduled for June 2020, make it difficult to muster political support 
for initiatives like the EITI. Accordingly, the MMHI has approached the European Bank for 
Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) and ADB to help fund EITI secretariat costs up to 2021. 
Meanwhile  the government  will  cover  an  increasing  share  of  EITI  secretariat  costs  before 
assuming full coverage in 2022. This is an opportunity to build momentum for the EITI by 
strengthening  the  legal  status  of  the  initiative,  avoiding  future  disruptions,  and  increasing 
transparency to improve trust in the industry. ADB has been an EITI partner organization since 
2008, and its support for the EITI in Mongolia will build on its support for EITI initiatives in other 
developing member countries.6 
 
6.  Public perception of the extractive industry in Mongolia has been deteriorating. More than 
75% of the population view corruption as common in Mongolia, with mining regularly cited as one 
of the main problem areas.7 In part this is because of a lack of public understanding of the 
extractive industry, and the failure of the extractive industry to engage the public in projects that 
directly  affect  them.  Furthermore,  confusion  over  how  the  central  government  and  local 
governments share responsibility for the industry fuels a perception that the industry is opaque 
and difficult to engage with. Some mining companies do try to ensure that local populations benefit 
from their presence, but this is not systematic or well regulated. Nonetheless, opportunities exist 
to  improve  information  dissemination  and  public  monitoring  of  activities  in  the  industry.8 
Opportunities include (i) the Computerized Mining Cadaster System; (ii) Mongolia’s Geological 
Information  Catalogue  System  or  MonGeoCat,  a  publicly  accessible  metadata  catalog  of 
geological data and maps; (iii) InfoRep, an e-reporting system for exploration and production; and 
(iv) the EITI e-reporting system. Improving the quality and transparency of information available 
to citizens will increase public understanding and make it easier for the public to engage with 
the industry. 
 
7.  Growing  opaqueness  and  complexity  threatens  to  slow  down  development  of  the 
extractive industry. Upstream development has already stalled: New exploration licenses are not 
being awarded and once the large Oyu Tolgoi copper mine moves into production in 2020 or 
2021, the pipeline for major mining projects will dry up entirely. Unless Mongolia creates a mining 
industry  that  engages  communities  and  presents  investors  with  a  transparent  and  stable 
                                                
5  A beneficial owner in respect of a company is the natural person(s) who directly or indirectly ultimately owns or 
controls the corporate entity. 
6  EITI. Partner Organisations. EITI partner organizations “provide support for good governance in the extractives 
sector, especially related to EITI international activities, and technical, financial and political support for in-country 
implementation and training.” 
7  The Asia Foundation. 2018. Survey on Perceptions and Knowledge of Corruption. Ulaanbaatar. 
8  Support was provided by the World Bank, the Australian government, the EBRD, and the Federal Institute for 
Geosciences and Natural Resources of the Government of Germany.

3 
environment, mining will eventually cease to be a driver of development. Supporting the EITI 
alone will not resolve the many challenges that threaten the extractive industry, but the EITI allows 
ADB, as Mongolia’s largest development partner, to involve the government, business, and civil 
society in its support. The EITI also provides ADB with an opportunity to better understand this 
critical  industry  in  Mongolia  and  explore  ways  to  work  with  the  government  to  improve 
management of the industry. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The  TA  is  aligned  with  the  following  impact:  transparency,  accountability,  and 
competitiveness of the extractive industry improved (footnote 1). The TA will have the following 
outcome: extractive industry governance improved.9 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
9.  Output 1: Commitment to the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative standard 
maintained and improved. The TA will support the government and the EITI secretariat to 
implement the EITI work plan—the implementation document of the EITI process in Mongolia that 
will support the country’s adherence to the EITI standard. Support will include recruiting and 
paying secretariat staff and covering secretariat costs until the end of 2021, in partnership with 
the EBRD, which will provide funding until August 2019, and the government, which will cover an 
increasing proportion of secretariat costs before assuming full coverage in 2022. Through this 
output, the multistakeholder group overseeing the EITI process will receive support to create a 
long-term  institutional  arrangement  for  the  EITI  secretariat  that  will  prevent  future 
funding disruptions.  
 
10.  Output 2: Legislation to improve transparency in the extractive industry identified. 
Through the TA, ADB will review legislation and structures in consultation with other industry 
stakeholders. ADB will propose draft legislation to improve transparency in the industry and 
strengthen the legal basis of the EITI secretariat. 
 
11.  Output 3: Review of opportunities for better information dissemination and public 
monitoring of extractive industry activities conducted. Under this output, ADB will review 
existing information systems and reports and identify ways to improve how they are used. ADB 
will then work with the government to communicate information on extractive industry activities to 
the public through publications and other means. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $888,200, of which $500,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6). The government will provide counterpart 
support in the form of staff remuneration, office space, logistics and administrative support, 
domestic transportation, and other in-kind contributions. In addition, the government will also 
finance and administer a cash contribution of $338,200, separate from ADB’s fund flow. Key 
expenditure items are in Appendix 2. 
 
                                                
9  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

4 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
13.  The TA will be implemented from 1 July 2019 to 31 December 2021. MMHI will be the 
executing agency and the implementing agency. The Mongolia Resident Mission (MNRM) will 
lead the TA and will take a one-ADB approach in this TA by working closely with relevant ADB 
departments. The multistakeholder working group that oversees the EITI process in Mongolia will 
oversee and provide guidance for the TA project. The resident mission will select, supervise, and 
evaluate consultants in consultation with the MMHI and the EITI working group; and procure 
goods. Consultants will organize and deliver project activities, including organizing workshops. 
There will be at least three workshops (inception, midterm, and final) in addition to planned 
capacity development under the TA. 
 
14.  TA  support  for  workshops  may  include  costs  related  to  venues,  equipment  rental, 
translation, printing and copying, meals, transport, lodging, logistics and administrative support, 
and other expenditures with prior agreement from ADB. In line with standard ADB procedures, 
the TA will not support the (i) executing agency’s management fees and related costs such as 
staff  salaries  and  allowances;  and  (ii)  use  of  executing  agency  resources  such  as  office 
accommodation, which will be provided as part of the counterpart contribution. The executing 
agency will provide office space and additional equipment. It will also provide access to utilities 
and telecommunication, including a broadband internet connection, for individual consultants. It 
will supply data and documents as required under the TA and will cover the cost of office utilities 
for  consultants.  To  maximize  the  effectiveness  of  TA  activities,  the  executing  agency  will 
designate a TA focal point with strong English-speaking and writing skills to facilitate TA activities 
and links to local government representatives and other stakeholders. 
 
15.  The executing agency will establish a separate advance payment facility in United States 
dollars at a commercial bank acceptable to ADB in coordination with the Ministry of Finance, 
following ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to 
time). This will be used to pay for workshops and training, surveys, publication of reports, and 
equipment costs. ADB assesses the executing agency as having the financial management 
capacity and internal controls to maintain records. 
 
16.  The implementation arrangements are summarized in the table.

17.  Consulting services. ADB will engage seven individual consultants to deliver the project. 
ADB will hire one international legal expert and six national consultants: one legal expert, one TA 
coordinator, and four staff for the EITI secretariat. Lump-sum or output-based contracts for 
consulting  services  will  be  considered  where  appropriate  and  possible.  ADB  will  engage 
consultants following the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its 
associated project administration instructions and/or staff instructions.10 Consultants will produce 
the TA outputs and deliverables effectively and in a timely manner, will organize and carry out all 
TA activities, and will report to the ADB project officer. ADB will evaluate TA progress during 
review mission workshops, based on the performance targets and indicators defined in the design 
and monitoring framework (footnote 9). 
 
18.  ADB’s procurement. ADB will procure a small amount of equipment to support the 
delivery of outputs, including office equipment, laptops, and/or tablets. The resident mission will 
undertake  procurement  and  will  transfer  all  equipment  to  MMHI  upon  project  completion. 
Procurement will follow the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and 
its associated project administration instructions and/or staff instructions. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to the 
Government of Mongolia for Improving Extractive Sector Governance, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board.
                                                
10 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).
